awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Knowledge Guided Machine Learning: A Framework for Accelerating Scientific Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
The success of machine learning (ML) in many applications where large-scale data is available has led to a growing anticipation of similar accomplishments in scientific disciplines. The use of data science is particularly promising in scientific problems involving processes that are not completely understood. However, a purely data-driven approach to modeling a physical process can be problematic. For example, it can create a complex model that is neither generalizable beyond the data on which it was trained nor physically interpretable. This problem becomes worse when there is not enough training data, which is quite common in science and engineering domains.  A machine learning model that is grounded by explainable theories stands a better chance at safeguarding against learning spurious patterns from the data that lead to non-generalizable performance. This is especially important when dealing with problems that are critical and associated with high risks (e.g., extreme weather or collapse of an ecosystem).  Hence, neither an ML-only nor a scientific knowledge-only approach can be considered sufficient for knowledge discovery in complex scientific and engineering applications. This project is developing novel techniques to explore the continuum between knowledge-based and ML models, where both scientific knowledge and data are integrated synergistically. Such integrated methods have the potential for accelerating discovery in a range of scientific and engineering disciplines. This project will train interdisciplinary scientists who are well versed in such methods and will disseminate results of the project via peer-reviewed publications, open-source software, and a series of workshops to engage the broader scientific community.

This project aims to develop a framework that uses the unique capability of data science models to automatically learn patterns and models from data, without ignoring the treasure of accumulated scientific knowledge. Specifically, the project builds the foundations of knowledge-guided machine learning (KGML) by exploring several ways of bringing scientific knowledge and machine learning models together using pilot applications from four domains: aquatic ecodynamics, climate and weather, hydrology, and translational biology. These pilot applications were selected because they are at tipping points where knowledge-guided machine learning can have a transformative effect.  KGML has the potential for providing scientists and engineers with new insights into their domains of interest and will require the development of innovative new machine learning approaches and architectures that can incorporate scientific principles. Scientific knowledge, KGML methods, and software developed in this project could potentially be extended to a wide range of scientific applications where mechanistic (also known as process-based) models are used.

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project on knowledge guided machine learning (KGML) has established and grown a new conceptual and analytical approach to environmental problems within the realm of lake ecology. With KGML, the power of two complementary approaches to modeling lake ecosystem dynamics, machine learning and process-based modeling, are melded to combine the strengths of each approach. Machine learning exploits information content of datasets, while process-based modeling represents ecological knowledge. Through KGML, the hybridization of these approaches has proven more effective at predicting lake temperature and water quality than either approach alone, especially under circumstances of modest data availability, which is common in lake monitoring programs. KGML has also led to more generalizable models with better prediction skill under new circumstances. For example, KGML lake temperature models trained with three seasons of data predict the fourth season well, despite not having been trained for that season. KGML phosphorus models have detected long and slow changes in lake nutrients missed by other models and have provided feedback to scientists on better understanding of biogeochemical mechanism in lakes. Accurate predictions of lake temperature and phosphorus dynamics are needed to understand whole-ecosystem nutrient budgets that underpin degraded water quality, such as formation of harmful algal blooms or onset of deep-water anoxia that limits lake habitability for valuable fish species. This research has provided another valuable lesson, which is that relatively simple process-based models perform well when hybridized with machine learning. Simple process-based models allow for rapid development, flexible design, and easy implementation, which makes their use more accessible to the scientific community. While implementation of simple process-based models within KGML requires skills in the use of machine learning, collaboration with computer scientists provides the needed expertise. The outcomes of the collaborations are greater than either discipline have been able to achieve alone. These successes have catalyzed a broad array of further research in academia and federal agencies. 

This project has introduced knowledge guided machine learning (KGML) to the lake ecology community and catalyzed research beyond its original institutional and collaborative scope. Two KGML workshops open to the entire scientific community drew >1,000 registrants, with hundreds of participants in aquatic sciences from around the world. As a result, scientists from KGML application domains, such as aquatic sciences, hydrology, and atmospheric scientists, have benefitted from the expertise of computer scientists, mathematicians, and statisticians and in many cases have formed new and productive collaborations. Collaborations have extended well into federal agencies, such as the USGS, which has adopted KGML as part of its water modeling strategy, and the EPA, which has entered into collaborative work on national scale water quality modeling. In the lake ecology community, KGML has become part of the nomenclature for new model development. Engagement of project personnel with members of the Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network (GLEON), which has nearly 1,000 members, has brought KGML into the realm of lake modeling working groups. The application of KGML within the context of GLEON?s graduate student initiatives has occurred within the GLEON Fellows Program. A graduate student training program called, Lake Expedition 2020 (LE2020), was launched with the overarching goal of determining changing lake area in the US. The expedition, which included 9 graduate students from different institutions, worked with computer scientists to use KGML to identify patterns of change 103,000 lakes. LE2020 students have given numerous talks and posters about the challenges and successes of transdisciplinary research that includes big data and cutting edge analyses. In addition, three postdoctoral fellows from aquatic ecology have been instrumental in the development of the ideas and techniques of KGML, and as a result have advanced their technical skills and greatly expanding their professional networks.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Paul C Hanson
